block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended June 2, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

THE DIANA CHRONICLES, by Tina Brown. (Doubleday, $27.50.) The former New Yorker editor perceptively highlights the media's role in the sordid domestic drama that pitted the Princess of Wales against Britain's royal family.
NINE, by Andrzej Stasiuk. Translated by Bill Johnston. (Harcourt, $23.) This Polish ''existential crime novel'' vividly evokes the scamming subsistence culture of the Warsaw underworld.
LONG TIME LEAVING: Dispatches From Up South, by Roy Blount Jr. (Knopf, $25.) Literate, good-humored essays on Southern culture.
THE PERFECT MAN, by Naeem Murr. (Random House; paper, $13.95.) The British-Indian hero of this novel comes of age in racist 1950s Missouri.
THE AGE OF ABUNDANCE: How Prosperity Transformed America's Politics and Culture, by Brink Lindsey. (Collins/HarperCollins, $26.95.) Affluence breeds libertarianism, Lindsey argues.
RELIGIOUS LITERACY: What Every American Needs to Know -- and Doesn't, by Stephen Prothero. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) A professor laments our declining knowledge of religion.
THE SUSHI ECONOMY: Globalization and the Making of a Modern Delicacy, by Sasha Issenberg. (Gotham, $26.) Sushi, and particularly the bluefin tuna, as an example of ''good'' globalization.

THE ZEN OF FISH: The Story of Sushi, From Samurai to Supermarket, by Trevor Corson. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) An often amusing history. THE COLLECTED STORIES, by Leonard Michaels. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Larky and profane, Michaels's sexually kinetic short stories stand alongside those of his best Jewish contemporaries, Grace Paley and Philip Roth.
SYLVIA, by Leonard Michaels. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux; paper, $13.) A fictionalized memoir, first published in 1992, about Michaels's first wife, Sylvia Bloch, whose troubled life ended in suicide.

TRAVELS WITH HERODOTUS, by Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by Klara Glowczewska. (Knopf, $25.) The only memoir by the Pole who was perhaps the world's best literary journalist.The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

1 THE GOOD GUY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) In a case of mistaken identity, an ordinary man finds himself at the center of a murder plot.
29 FOR ONE MORE DAY, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $21.95.) A troubled man gets a last chance to reconnect and restore his relationship with his dead mother.
5 3 4 THE 6TH TARGET, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) In San Francisco, children are disappearing, and Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women's Murder Club investigate.
6 4 3 INVISIBLE PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) The Minneapolis detective Lucas Davenport finds connections between the murder of several elderly residents and a political scandal.

1 SACRIFICE, by Karen Traviss. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.) Jacen, the son of Han and Leia Solo, must murder someone close to him to become a Sith lord; a ''Star Wars'' novel.
9 5 3 BAD LUCK AND TROUBLE, by Lee Child. (Delacorte, $26.) Jack Reacher must discover who is hunting down members of a team of former military investigators.
10 7 5 THE YIDDISH POLICEMEN'S UNION, by Michael Chabon. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) A detective investigates a neighbor's murder in a Jewish settlement in Alaska.
11 8 6 SIMPLE GENIUS, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.99.) Two former Secret Service agents investigate a scientist's murder while one battles her own demons.
12 12 13 NINETEEN MINUTES, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $26.95.) The aftermath of a high school shooting reveals the fault lines in a small New Hampshire town.
13* 9 5 RANT, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The ''oral biography'' of a serial killer.
1 LAWMAN, by Diana Palmer. (HQN, $24.95.) An F.B.I. agent discovers that the trail of the escaped child predator he is tracking leads in an unexpected direction.
2 FALLING MAN, by Don DeLillo. (Scribner, $26.) The effect of 9/11 on a middle-class Manhattan family.

1 1 2 THE ASSAULT ON REASON, by Al Gore. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) How the Bush administration has degraded the political environment through secrecy, fear and the rejection of fact-based reasoning.
2 2 2 THE REAGAN DIARIES, by Ronald Reagan. Edited by Douglas Brinkley. (HarperCollins, $35.) Selections from the 40th president's daily White House diaries.
3 4 5 GOD IS NOT GREAT, by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $24.99.) Religion as a malignant force in the world.
4 3 8 EINSTEIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) A biography based on newly released personal letters.
5 6 16 A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing spree and his return to humanity.

6 8 5 ANIMAL, VEGETABLE, MIRACLE, by Barbara Kingsolver with Steven L. Hopp and Camille Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) The novelist and her family spend a year eating homegrown or local food; an argument for sustainable agriculture.
7 5 4 PRESIDENTIAL COURAGE, by Michael Beschloss. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Profiles of nine presidents who had the courage to make unpopular decisions.
8 7 3 JESUS OF NAZARETH, by Benedict XVI. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The pope discusses Jesus' identity as revealed in the Gospels.

9* 9 7 WHERE HAVE ALL THE LEADERS GONE?, by Lee Iacocca. (Scribner, $25.) The former C.E.O. of Chrysler protests the lack of political and business leadership on issues like health care and energy policy.
10 10 3 RICKLES' BOOK, by Don Rickles with David Ritz. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A memoir by the insult comedian.
11 11 6 THE BLACK SWAN, by Nassim Nicholas Taleb. (Random House, $26.95.) The role of the unexpected.
1 THE CANON, by Natalie Angier. (Houghton Mifflin, $27.) A refresher course on the fundamentals of science.
13 16 2 BROTHERS, by David Talbot. (Free Press, $28.) An assessment of John F. Kennedy's administration and a plea for a new effort to uncover the truth about his assassination.
14 14 4 TALES FROM Q SCHOOL, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $26.99.) Inside the 2005 PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament, from the author of ''A Good Walk Spoiled.''
106 THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) A columnist for The Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy.
102 FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $27.95.) A maverick scholar and a journalist apply economic theory to nearly everything.
